Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story: It was Sunday evening, the time I always reserved for my weekly phone call with my parents. I could already picture my mom waiting by the phone, eager to hear about my week, and my dad ready with his usual questions about work and whether I was eating well. Just as I was about to dial, my phone buzzed with a message from Maya: “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m totally lost with this bookshelf and the instructions make no sense.” I knew she’d been having a rough week, and she rarely asked for help. My parents expected me to call on time, and I didn’t want to worry them or make them feel unimportant. But Maya was counting on me too, and I could hear the frustration in her voice through her text. I stared at my phone, torn between the comfort of my family’s routine and the urgency of my friend’s plea, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
